concept.title: Valve Timing in Internal Combustion Engines
concept.shortdesc: Precise valve timing is crucial for engine performance, determining the exact moments when intake and exhaust valves open and close during the engine cycle.

section.title: Valve Timing Fundamentals
section.p: Valve timing is typically set at the factory during engine construction. Retiming becomes necessary only when critical components such as the cam shaft, time gears, or valves are removed during engine overhaul.

section.title: Timing Gear Configuration
section.p: Proper valve timing requires precise gear alignment:

ul.li: The first cam must point in a direction opposite to the zero mark
Time gears must mesh so that the zero-marked tooth on the small time gear is positioned between two teeth on the large gear at the zero point

section.title: Valve Opening and Closing Specifications
section.p: Precise valve timing involves specific measurements:

strow.stentry: At top center (5/16" above cylinder casting)

section.title: Push Rod and Valve Stem Clearance

ul.li: Optimal clearance: Midpoint between maximum and minimum (approximately 3/64")
Measurement should be taken when the push rod is on the heel of the cam

section.title: Firing Order
section.p: For the specific engine model described, the cylinder firing order is: 1, 2, 4, 3.
